At 22:36 23/08/2004, Colin wrote:
>Hi Ken,



> >But the idea of only adding a % of excess and disjoint genes I am
> >unsure about.  If a complex of genes has formed that are all
> >interdependent, that could be a bad move.  Maybe safer would be to
> >just make adding *all* the excess and disjoint genes probabilistic.
> >
> >
>Good point.

Or, does that imply that the two individuals are too different to breed 
successfully anyway?

If you had a set of genes which were all in one parent, mutually 
interdependent, and beneficial, could that be a definition of a "module"?

I guess nature gets around this as follows:

- when new genes first appear they are exchanged between individuals so 
similar that they tend to get the same support framework from both parents.

- as mutual interdependence between genes grows (over very long periods) 
the genes tend to get shuffled close together so that they do crossover as 
a single unit

e.g. nature would have the same problem, except that it uses a lot more 
resources and proceeds far slower

         Ian Badcoe
